Expectation1: Engage in spiritual study and reflection
Situation1: The nun has a quiet afternoon and plans to spend time in personal spiritual reading and contemplation.
Expectation2: Follow all instructions provided by election officials
Situation2: Officials ask voters with last names A–M to move to a newly opened line, even though the original line is moving faster.
Story:
I had set aside this afternoon for spiritual reading, a rare stretch of quiet in the convent’s small library. My heart was eager for the silence, the gentle turning of pages, the chance to reflect and listen for God’s voice. But today was also election day, and I had promised my community I would fulfill my civic duty. At the polling station, I joined the line, rosary in my pocket, mind still half in prayer. Suddenly, an official called out: “Voters with last names A–M, please move to the new line.” My last name began with “B.” The new line was longer, slower, but the instructions were clear.

I hesitated, torn. As a nun, I felt compelled to honor my commitment to spiritual discipline, to return quickly to my sacred reading. But as a voter, I was expected to obey the officials, to respect the process and set an example of integrity. The minutes ticked by, my heart pulled between obedience to my faith’s rhythm and obedience to civic order. I stood there, wrestling with the weight of both callings, uncertain which voice to heed.
